citation.article-title: Delimiting the genus Staphylococcus through description of Macrococcus caseolyticus gen. nov., comb. nov. and Macrococcus equipercicus sp. nov., and Macrococcus bovicus sp. no. and Macrococcus carouselicus sp. nov.

p.s: Macrococcus (Ma.cro.coc'cus. Gr. adj. macrus large; Gr. masc. n. kokkos a grain or berry; M.L. masc. n. Macrococcus a large coccus)
The description below is based on data collected on the species Staphylococcus caseolyticus (Schleifer et al., 1982; Endl et al., 1983; Schleifer, 1986) and data from this study.
Cells are spherical or coccoid, Gram-positive, non-motile, non-encapsulated and do not produce endospores.
They are 1-1-2.5 μm in diameter and are larger than the cells of Staphylococcus species when comparisons are made of cells grown on the same medium.
Metabolism is mainly respiratory; growth is chemoorganotrophic and only marginally facultatively anaerobic.
They are catalase- and oxidase- positive, staphylocoagulase-, ornithine-decarboxylase-, alkaline-phosphatase-, β-glucuronidase and β-galactosidase-negative, non-halophilic and mesophilic.
They are resistant to bacitracin and lysozyme, and susceptible to furazolidone.
The peptidoglycan type is L-Lys-Gly3-4, L-Ser, and only one of the four macrococcal species, i.e. Macrococcus caseolyticus, appears to contain cell-wall teichoic acid.
The genome size range is approximately 1500-1800 kb.
The G + C content of the DNA is 38-45 mol% [as determined by the thermal denaturation method (Marmur & Doty, 1962)].
The type species is Macrococcus equipercicus.
It was selected as the type species in place of M. caseolyticus, the first described species of the group, because it is the most typical of the cluster of four species now recognized.
